data.question: Who is credited with the synthesis and crystal structures analysis of barium iodide adducts?
What solvent was used to isolate compounds 3 and 4 from barium iodide?
What is the coordination number of barium in BaI2?
Which compound forms a three-dimensional structure containing a trigonal prism of I atoms?
What is the coordination number for iodine in compound 2?
Which compound has a one-dimensional structure with barium atoms bridged by two p2-I atoms?
Why do compounds 1-4 have similarities with the solid-state structure of BaI2?
data.answer: Because they can be derived from the solid-state structure of BaI2 and show a transition in coordination numbers and dimensionality.

data.question: Does the coordination number of iodine decrease from BaI2 to compound 1?
Is compound 4 zero-dimensional?
Does the coordination number for barium remain the same from BaI2 to compound 2?
Is the coordination number for iodine in compound 4 higher than in compound 1?
Does compound 3 decompose at room temperature under elimination of solvent molecules?
Is the Ba-I bond length in compound 4 longer than in BaI2?
Does the solvation process with water afford compound 1?
Can the structural features of the barium iodide adducts be derived from the solid-state structure of BaI2?
Does compound 2 form a two-dimensional layered structure?
What is the effect of decreasing dimensionality on the Ba-I bond length?
data.answer: The Ba-I bond length becomes shorter as the dimensionality decreases.

data.question: Is the coordination number of iodine in compound 3 two?
Does the transition from the solid-state structure of BaI2 to compounds 1 and 2 involve a decrease in the coordination number for iodine?
Are the compounds 1-4 based on the BaI2 structure able to form new structures when combined?
data.answer: Future investigations are required to determine whether the compounds can be combined to produce new structures.
